nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) misrepresents long-term technological energy transitions and produces spurious carbon price inflation, undermining policy relevance
Prominent IAMs commonly use CES or nested CES formulations to model substitution among energy and production factors
Applying CES to technical factor substitution over long periods is theoretically and practically inappropriate because CES is share-preserving and assumes constant elasticity

We implement a representative CES two-good model substituting fossil energy (F) with renewable energy (R), derive MRTS and price relations, and compute required R and carbon tax for different initial shares and elasticities

The CES example yields exponentially increasing R quantities required to replace F and an exponentially rising carbon price as substitution progresses; outcomes are highly sensitive to elasticity parameter
Analytic derivation (appendix), simulated graphs (Figures 1 and 2), and sensitivity runs demonstrate CES-driven exponential substitution quantities and carbon tax trajectories
State-of-the-art IAMs (examples: GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE, MARKAL hybrids) employ nested CES, CRESH, Leontief or Cobb-Douglas structures for energy and production which embed CES behavior

Model outputs from these IAMs exhibit the same artifact: carbon prices rising monotonically or exponentially to very high levels late-century (hundreds to thousands USD/tCO2), and constrained technology mixes dominated by pre-included options like CCS, nuclear, biomass

Relying on CES-driven IAM outputs causes three policy distortions: price diversion (focus on pricing instead of physical planning), sticker shock (political paralysis from extreme estimated carbon prices), and technological myopia (overreliance on incumbent, modeled technologies)
Empirical history of technological and energy transitions follows S-curve diffusion with dynamically changing (increasing then saturating) ease of substitution, not constant elasticity

A plausible methodological modification is to implement dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (linearly or exponentially changing rho) to emulate S-curve substitution within existing model frameworks

Simulations with dynamically decreasing elasticity produce more realistic substitution trajectories and carbon price behavior (peaking or bounded by substitute cost) compared to constant-elasticity CES

IAMs also suffer from external structural shortcomings unrelated to CES: sensitive and politically loaded discount rate choices, arbitrary or optimistic climate damage functions, GDP-as-welfare assumptions, and underestimation of fat-tail catastrophic risks

Given CES artifacts and other IAM limitations, policy-relevant long-term energy-climate modeling should shift toward approaches that incorporate physical energy principles and realistic substitution dynamics

Policy recommendation: supplement or replace price-only strategies with physical planning and deployment targets for renewables and storage, and adopt dynamic-elasticity or physics-driven models to guide transition decisions
